par.text: Rubidium is a silvery-white, very soft and light metal, a good conductor of electricity. Rubidium and its compounds impart a violet colour to a flame. Rubidium is very reactive and has to be stored in kerosene. A freshly cut surface is lustrous. On contact with air rubidium ignites spontaneously to produce rubidium oxide – R
O. It reacts violently with water, displacing hydrogen. Its name is derived from the Latin word
- dark red. Rubidium was discovered in 1860 by German scientists: the chemist Robert Wilhelm Bunsen and physicist Gustav Robert Kirchhoff.
